A plan had now been agreed upon which heldpromise of being accepted. This plan provided for (a) A tapering subsidy;together with(b) A lump sum, not related to any specific period, which shouldbe held in trust for the Emperor to enable him to dealwith unforeseeable expenditure in the transitional period.It had been arranged that Sir Philip Mitchell should negotiatethe Agreement, but it had been left to the Foreign Secretary todetermine whether Sir Philip or Mr. Howe, the Minister-designate,should sign the new agreement.The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that the financial position was now satisfactory, except that some difficulties seemed likely to arise as to the medium in which payment should be made.The Foreign Secretary and the Secretary of State for Warexpressed themselves as satisfied with the settlement which had beenreached.The Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs said that he had communicated the decisions reached to Field-Marshal Smuts, but had not asked for his comments.The War Cabinet: Took note, with approval, of the settlement reached, and asked that copies of the draft Agreement should be circulated to the War Cabinet for their information. He said that His Majesty theKing had. raised some objection to the proposed confermentof a. peerage on Colonel the Right Hon. Josiah Wedgwood,D.S.0.,M.P., on the ground that he had been divorced.The Prime Minister read to the War Cabinet theletter received from His Majesty the King, togetherwith a statement made by Colonel Wedgwood at the timeof his divorce and published in his Life, explaining the'ffull circumstances.It was felt that, in the circumstances, there was no real stigma attaching to Colonel Wedgwood in the matter.It was also poin^ out that, since his divorce, hehad been made a member of the Privy Council. It was raised by the King, which related to the conferment of hereditary honours .It was also pointed out that a peerage had beenconferred on Lord Riddell after he had been divorced.Some discussion took place as to whether it wasin fact possible to dis criminate between one divorce case and another, the general (but not unanimous) view being that some discrimination must be exercised.THE PRIME MINISTER also corrected a statement whichhe had made when this matter had last been discussed bythe War Cabinet, to the effect that Colonel Wedgwood hadbeen told1that it was proposed to recommend his name toaltogether meet the point

He had written to Colonel Wedgwood as the result of the unfortunatestatement which the latter had made in the United States,and had explained that, in the circumstances, it would heimpossible to proceed with the recommendation, at anyrate for the time being.At the end-of the discussion THE PRIME ministers aid that he would write to the King and say that thematter had been discussed in Cabinet and that the unanimousview had. been to adhere to the recommendation in ColonelWedgwood's case, on the understanding that it would notbe regarded as a precedent in regard to the confermentof hereditary honours on the "guilty" party in a divorce.He ask.ed, however, that the War Cabinet would allow himsome little latitude in the matter, having regard to the strong views which His Majesty the King held on thissubject.
